verses.text: If you see your brother’s ox or sheep straying, do not ignore it; you must take it back to your brother.
verses.comment: This command establishes love for neighbor and responsibility for others' property, highlighting God's law of charity. Jesus expands on this in the Parable of the Good Samaritan.

verses.text: If your brother does not live near you or you do not know who he is, then bring the animal to your own house and keep it with you until your brother claims it; then you shall return it to him.
verses.comment: The law clarifies practical care for what belongs to others, requiring personal stewardship and patience—a principle echoed in Jesus' teaching on stewardship.

verses.text: You shall do the same with his donkey, with his clothes, and with anything your brother loses and you find; you must not ignore it.
verses.comment: The call to act justly covers all property, reinforcing the law of love with practical application.

verses.text: If you see your brother’s donkey or ox fallen on the road, do not ignore it. Help him lift it up.
verses.comment: The command to assist in hardship foreshadows carrying each other's burdens, as taught in the New Testament.

verses.text: A woman shall not wear a man’s clothing, nor shall a man put on a woman’s garment, for everyone who does these things is an abomination to the LORD your God.
verses.comment: Emphasizing God’s distinctions in creation, this law addresses the importance of honoring the order set by God.

verses.text: If you come across a bird’s nest by the road, in any tree or on the ground, with young ones or eggs, and the mother sitting on the young or on the eggs, you shall not take the mother with the young.
verses.comment: This mercy extends God’s care to creation, instructing reverence for life and the stewardship required of God’s people.

verses.text: You shall surely let the mother go, but you may take the young for yourself, that it may go well with you, and you may live long.
verses.comment: The promise ‘that it may go well with you’ echoes the fifth commandment, suggesting blessings for obedience to God’s detailed care laws.

verses.text: When you build a new house, you shall make a parapet for your roof, so that you may not bring guilt of blood upon your house if anyone falls from it.
verses.comment: Safety laws recognize the communal dimensions of sin and responsibility. The concern for the wellbeing of others points to a communal ethic that is vital in the New Covenant.

verses.text: You shall not sow your vineyard with two kinds of seed, or the whole crop will be forfeited—the seed you have sown and the yield of the vineyard.
verses.comment: Mixed seed laws point to the requirement for spiritual purity and separation. Paul applies similar language to the gathering of believers (2 Cor. 6:14-18).

verses.text: You shall not plow with an ox and a donkey together.
verses.comment: This law teaches against mixing incompatible things, pointing to deeper symbolic divisions in God’s law about holiness.

verses.text: You shall not wear a garment made of wool and linen together.
verses.comment: Garments mixed of wool and linen again figuratively represent pure, undivided devotion in worship and life.

verses.text: You shall make yourself fringes on the four corners of the cloak with which you cover yourself.
verses.comment: Fringes (tzitzit) function as a visible reminder of God’s commandments. Jesus wore such, connecting Old and New Covenants in visible obedience.

verses.text: If a man takes a wife and goes in to her and then despises her,
verses.comment: Marriage laws highlight the sacredness and binding nature of marriage, preparing for the full revelation of the sacramental nature of marriage.

verses.text: and brings charges against her, saying, ‘I took this woman, but when I came near her, I did not find evidence of her virginity,’
verses.comment: The gravity placed on sexual purity is a sign of the holiness God prepares for His people ahead of the Messiah.

verses.text: then the father and mother of the young woman shall take and bring out the evidence of the young woman’s virginity to the elders of the city at the gate.
verses.comment: Elders serve as witnesses, foreshadowing the Church’s future role in safeguarding the integrity of sacraments.

verses.text: And the young woman’s father shall say to the elders, ‘I gave my daughter to this man as a wife, and he has despised her.’
verses.comment: Parental responsibility and the community’s role in justice highlight the family as foundational in God’s plan.

verses.text: ‘Now he has accused her of shameful things, saying, “I did not find in your daughter evidence of virginity,” but here is the evidence of my daughter’s virginity.’ And they shall spread the garment before the elders of the city.
verses.comment: This ceremony underscores the importance of honesty, family honor, and public truth—all fulfilled in Christ’s upholding of the Law.

verses.text: Then the elders of that city shall take the man and punish him.
verses.comment: Upholding justice preserves the purity and order of God’s people, prefiguring the Church’s guardianship of moral discipline.

verses.text: They shall fine him a hundred shekels of silver, giving them to the father of the young woman, because he has spread a bad name about a virgin of Israel. She shall remain his wife; he may not divorce her all his days.
verses.comment: The indissolubility of marriage is emphasized, reflecting Christ’s later teaching that marriage is a permanent covenant.

verses.text: But if the accusation is true, and evidence of virginity is not found for the young woman,
verses.comment: God’s people are called to personal holiness and accountability.

verses.text: then they shall bring out the young woman to the door of her father’s house, and the men of her city shall stone her to death with stones, because she has done a disgraceful thing in Israel, to play the harlot in her father’s house. So you shall purge the evil from among you.
verses.comment: The severity of the Old Law points to the seriousness of sin and the need for mercy—fulfilled in Christ’s forgiveness (see John 8:3-11).

verses.text: If a man is found lying with another man’s wife, both of them shall die—the man who lay with the woman, and the woman. So you shall purge the evil from Israel.
verses.comment: Adultery’s seriousness prefigures Christ’s teaching on the sanctity of marital union.

verses.text: If there is a young woman who is a virgin, betrothed to a man, and another man meets her in the city and lies with her,
verses.comment: Betrothal was considered binding, foreshadowing the New Covenant understanding of marriage’s sacred preeminence.

verses.text: then you shall bring both of them out to the gate of that city and stone them to death with stones—the young woman, because she did not cry for help in the city; and the man, because he violated his neighbor’s wife. So you shall purge the evil from among you.
verses.comment: The law distinguishes between consensual sin and coercion, setting the groundwork for deeper moral discernment in Christ’s teaching.

verses.text: But if in the open country a man meets a young woman who is betrothed, and the man seizes her and lies with her, then only the man who lay with her shall die.
verses.comment: Here mercy is shown to the victim and justice for the aggressor, echoing God’s justice tempered by mercy in the New Covenant (Jas. 2:13).

verses.text: But you shall do nothing to the young woman; she has committed no sin worthy of death. For just as when a man rises against his neighbor and kills him, so is this case.
verses.comment: Sin cannot be presumed. This establishes the principle of full investigation and truth—practiced in the life of the early Church.

verses.text: For he found her in the open country, and though the betrothed young woman cried for help, there was no one to rescue her.
verses.comment: Situational justice is a hallmark of God’s law, preparing the way for Christ’s fulfillment of perfect justice.

verses.text: If a man meets a young woman who is a virgin, who is not betrothed, and seizes her and lies with her, and they are discovered,
verses.comment: This law aims at repairing harm through restitution and family formation, underlying the sanctity of the marital bond.

verses.text: then the man who lay with her shall give to the young woman’s father fifty shekels of silver, and she shall be his wife, because he has violated her. He may not divorce her all his days.
verses.comment: Marriage is indissoluble once established, prefiguring the permanence of the marital covenant affirmed by Jesus.

verses.text: A man shall not take his father’s wife, nor uncover his father’s nakedness.
verses.comment: This law upholds the sanctity of family relations and foreshadows Christ’s perfect fulfillment of the Law.
